DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua Devalues Currency
DOC.TEXT: The Nicaraguan government on Friday devalued its currency for the 40th time this year and raised the price of gasoline and public transportation. The move by the Nicaraguan Central Bank brought the official rate to 38,150 cordobas per dollar. The previous exchange was 36,330 cordobas per dollar. Nicaragua regularly devalues the cordoba because of inflation and to keep the price for exports competitive. After 1988's 33,000 percent inflation, the government took drastic austerity measures earlier this year. It slashed the budget nearly in half by laying off 40,000 government workers and restricting credit. Alejandro Martinez, minister of planning and budget, said recently that the government's austerity program ``has shown positive effects'' _ inflation this year had been lowered to ``only 1,500 percent.'' Friday's price rises increased by 30 percent the rate for urban and inter-city public bus fares. Nicaragua raises the price of gasoline to keep it at a constant dollar price because it is dependent on imports, for which it must pay scarce dollars.
